required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Lateral Neck Flexor Endurance and Hyperlaxity
clinical_study.official_title: Lateral Neck Flexor Endurance in Individuals With and Without Systemic Hyperlaxity

brief_summary.textblock: The lateral neck flexor endurance test has been proposed to assess for unilateral muscular deficits. It is not known if individuals with hyperlaxity have different muscular endurance than individuals without hyperlaxity.

detailed_description.textblock: Thirty individuals with systemic hyperlaxity as determined with the Beighton scale will be assessed for lateral neck flexor endurance and compared to age and gender matched controls. Basic demographic information will be collected, and all individuals will report Neck Disability Index (NDI) and Numeric Pain Rating Scales (NPRS) for their neck, as well duration of any neck pain. All participants will then undergo testing of lateral neck flexor muscle endurance, repeated twice on each side. Average hold times will be compared for individuals with hyperlaxity (5 or greater on Beighton scale) and the healthy age and gender matched controls. Analysis will also include covariates of NDI scores, pain scores, and chronicity of symptoms.

secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of systemic hyperlaxity, 0-9 points, higher indicates greater hyperlaxity
Questionnaire assessing impact of neck symptoms on function, 0-100 points, higher score indicates greater disability
assessment of neck pain, 0-10 with higher indicating greater levels of pain

arm_group.description: 30 individuals with systemic hyperlaxity as defined by a score of 5 or greater on the Beighton Hypermobility Scale
30 healthy, age and gender matched individuals without hyperlaxity

intervention.description: Individuals will maintain the head in a neutral position off the ground in sidelying for as long as possible.

study_pop.textblock: Individuals between the ages of 18-60 with and without systemic hyperlaxity
